Security settings¶

Microsoft Office¶

To ensure that the Office Add-In OfficeLink distributed by CONTACT is always executed in an unmodified and intact state, the add-in is digitally signed with a certificate belonging to CONTACT and provided by the certification provider DigiCert Inc.. This also allows the highest possible security level for add-ins to remain set in Microsoft Office in the Trust Center. However, when installing the OfficeLink Add-In on conversion servers, there are some special settings in the Trust Center which must be taken into account. These are explained in the chapter about the DCS Plug-In.

Microsoft Windows¶

When installing the OfficeLink add-in, there should be no Windows warning dailog that, for example, the MSI installer is from an untrusted publisher. If this is the case, then the used Windows is not regularly supplied with up-to-date root certificates, either manually or automatically via Windows Update. In addition, each time the add-in is loaded, Windows uses the Certificate Revocation List (CRL) to check whether the certificate used for OfficeLink is still valid. Since the CRL stored in Windows is valid only for about 30 days, it must also be updated regularly manually or automatically via the Windows kernel. If no up-to-date CRL can be found (e.g. because no Internet connection exists or special DNS names cannot be resolved), the loading time of the add-in can be slowed down in such a way that it is aborted with misleading Microsoft Office error messages. This behavior is part of Windows and not due to the architecture of the add-in. If a regular update of the CRL cannot be ensured, this feature can alternatively be deactivated in the Internet Explorer settings. To do this, uncheck the checkbox Check for publisher's certificate revocation in the Security area of the Advanced tab.
